![Ko'ko' comes back from 'extinction in the
wild'](https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/postguam.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/8/6d/86db6294-1d61-11ea-9ebd-5f179aa701de/5df314c087323.image.png)

__

**STILL 'CRITICALLY ENDANGERED':** A ko'ko', or Guam rail, is released into
the wild in 2010. The ko'ko' is the second bird – the first was the California
condor – in history to be downgraded from "extinct in the wild" to "critically
endangered" on the Red List of Threatened Species. Photo courtesy of Ginger
Haddock/Fernbird Photography

**CATCH, BREED, RELEASE:** Celestino Aguon, chief of the Guam Department of
Agriculture's Division of Aquatic and Wildlife Resources, releases a ko'ko'
into the wild in 2010. Aguon helped capture the remaining birds in the wild as
a wildlife technician before the ko'ko' went extinct. Photo courtesy of Ginger
Haddock/Fernbird Photography

**LITTLE SUETTE:** A young ko'ko' named Suette is one of the 131 birds in the
Ko'ko' Recovery Program at the Guam Department of Agriculture's Division of
Aquatic and Wildlife Resources. "Suette" means "lucky" in CHamoru. Haruo
Simion/Guam Daily Post

A major success in nature conservation is realized here on Guam with the Guam
rail, or ko'ko', being downgraded from "extinct in the wild" to "critically
endangered" on the Red List of Threatened Species by the International Union
of Conservation of Nature. The ko'ko' is the second bird – the first was the
California condor – in history to make such a comeback.

Laura Duenas, a wildlife biologist with the Ko'ko' Recovery Program under the
Division of Aquatic and Wildlife Resources at the Guam Department of
Agriculture, said the achievement could be a "light at the end of the tunnel"
for other species.

"The ko'ko' is just our trailblazer, but it leads the way for everyone else,"
Duenas said.

In the 1960s, about 60,000 ko'ko' were found in the wild. But as the number of
invasive brown tree snakes grew, the ko'ko' started dwindling, said Duenas.

"The disappearance of the birds were mimicking the observations of the snake.
That's how they were able to draw the connection between the snake coming to
Guam and the disappearance of the bird," she said.

In the '80s, about 20 years later, only about 21 to 24 of the birds were left
in the wild.

In 1984, Guam's native bird was added to the endangered species list.

"And by 1987, we were able to catch 21 birds and bring them into captivity,"
Duenas said.

But breeding the birds in captivity took time and trial and error to find
success. Creating "dating profiles" to determine which birds would make a
compatible match, and testing difference methods of releasing them paid off.
And by the late '90s, bigger numbers of ko'ko' were being released back into
the wild on Rota and Cocos Island.

"We have been doing this for 30 years. It took a while to put all of those
pieces of information together to get to where we are today," Duenas said.

The ko'ko' live for about three to five years in the wild but can live longer,
"depending on the amount of predation pressure and food availability," Duenas
said. A healthy female ko'ko' can have about 36 chicks a year.

In captivity, the birds can live for about 15 years, but they tend to have
health issues after about 10 years, she said.

The next goal for the program is to start getting the ko'ko' back on Guam
using established source populations.

"Within the last five years, we have actually had populations that we believe
are sustainable (on Rota)," Duenas said.

She said the Division of Aquatic and Wildlife Resources is already looking at
suitable areas for release and working on snake control and habitat control,
"to get the forests back into the shape they should be for our birds."

About 200 ko'ko' are now in the wild on Rota and approximately another 60 are
on Cocos Island.

The program's success not only means a brighter future for the ko'ko' species,
but it also can be a glimpse of what can be done for other endangered species.

"If Guam can actually do this, bring our birds back and control snakes,
eradicate the snakes, imagine what that could be for everywhere else in the
world," Duenas said. "We are making progress, and we are bringing them back."

# Zara clothing chain under fire for 'Pepe' skirt

## Clothing chain with history of bad choices pulls item from some sites.

By [ AMY SPIRO](https://www.jpost.com/author/amy-spiro)  

APRIL 19, 2017 15:41

[ ![Email](https://images.jpost.com/image/upload/f_auto,fl_lossy/Icons/mail-
icon-small.svg) ]( "Share with mail: Zara clothing chain under fire for 'Pepe'
skirt") [
![Twitter](https://images.jpost.com/image/upload/f_auto,fl_lossy/Icons/twitter-
icon-small.svg) ]( "Share on twitter: Zara clothing chain under fire for
'Pepe' skirt") [
![Facebook](https://images.jpost.com/image/upload/f_auto,fl_lossy/Icons/fb-
icon-small.svg) ]( "Share on facebook: Zara clothing chain under fire for
'Pepe' skirt") [ ![fb-
messenger](https://images.jpost.com/image/upload/f_auto,fl_lossy/Icons/messenger-
icon-small.svg) ]( "Share on fb-messenger: Zara clothing chain under fire for
'Pepe' skirt")

Zara clothing chain under fire for 'Pepe' skirt

(photo credit: screenshot)

International retail chain Zara appears to have pulled a skirt from many of
its sites after coming under fire for the cartoon frog painted on the item.

Many pointed out that the image on the skirt, released this week as part of
Zara's "oil on denim" line, bears a striking resemblance to "Pepe the Frog."

Pepe, originally created by illustrator Matt Furie, became the preferred
symbol of white nationalists during the 2016 US presidential campaign. The
image began to circulate alongside racist and antisemitic imagery so much that
the Anti-Defamation League listed it as a hate symbol last year, noting that
"the use of racist and bigoted versions of Pepe memes seems to be increasing,
not decreasing." The ADL did note that not all usages of the image are
antisemitic or racist.

After the uproar, the skirt, designed by Spanish artist Mario de Santiago, was
pulled from the US, Canada and UK Zara websites. But as of Wednesday
afternoon, the skirt was [still available on the Israel
site](https://www.zara.com/il/en/trf/oil-on-denim/ripped-denim-mini-skirt-
with-cartoon-design-c601001p4683077.html) for NIS 199, as well as many other
countries including Mexico, Lebanon, India and China.

In response to a request for comment from _The Jerusalem Post_ , Zara's
headquarters defended the design, and said it "is only available in selected
markets."

The retailer said Santiago drew inspiration from a wall painting he drew four
years ago, and that "there is absolutely no link to the suggested theme." Zara
provided a link to a video of Santiago drawing the mural four years ago, which
includes a frog, though a more lifelike one.

The clothing chain did not respond to further questions on the availability of
the skirt in certain markets, and the reason for pulling it from others.

This is far from the first time Zara, which is headquartered in Spain, has
come under fire.

In 2014, it pulled a [striped baby shirt, adorned with a yellow
star,](https://www.jpost.com/Diaspora/Zara-kids-shirt-that-looks-like-Nazi-
concentration-camp-garb-sparks-outrage-372481) after customers noted its eerie
resemblance to concentration camp uniforms. Zara apologized for the item, and
said on Twitter that the shirt was "inspired by the sheriff's stars from the
classic western films."

In 2007, the retail giant withdrew a purse it had been selling after a
customer discovered it had been adorned with swastikas amid the floral design.
Zara spokeswoman Susan Suette said the store did not realize the design was
there: "Had the symbol been seen, we would not have sourced that particular
handbag."

](https://share.flipboard.com/bookmarklet/popout?title=Syracuse+Fans+Need+To+Do+Less+Other+Stuff+And+More+Buying+SU+Football+Tickets&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nunesmagician.com%2F2010%2F10%2F13%2F1749538%2Fsyracuse-fans-needs-to-do-less-other-stuff-and-more-buying-su&v=2) * [ Email ](mailto:?subject=Syracuse%20Fans%20Need%20To%20Do%20Less%20Other%20Stuff%20And%20More%20Buying%20SU%20Football%20Tickets&body=%0A%0Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.nunesmagician.com%2F2010%2F10%2F13%2F1749538%2Fsyracuse-fans-needs-to-do-less-other-stuff-and-more-buying-su) ![via blog.syracuse.com](https://cdn.vox- cdn.com/thumbor/ZlQW6Ermc4MD1HBmi84dhaDtWG4=/10x0:442x288/1200x800/filters:focal\(10x0:442x288\)/cdn.vox- cdn.com/imported_assets/566001/large_021308sugtown3.jpg) via [blog.syracuse.com](http://blog.syracuse.com/orangebasketball/2008/02/large_021308SUGtown3.jpg) Between the excitement over a 4-1 start, Homecoming, the [Orange- Out](http://www.nunesmagician.com/2010/10/11/1744399/syracuse-vs-pitt-orange- out-warning-in-effect), the[ ticket deals](http://www.nunesmagician.com/2010/10/5/1733047/syracuse-is-basically- daring-you-not-to-attend-the-su-pitt-game) and the fact that it's Pitt, you'd think[ it would be a foregone conclusion that the Dome will close to selling out](http://espn.go.com/blog/bigeast/post/_/id/13643/orange-uprising-syracuse- gaining-attention) at this point for Saturday's game. Much to our chagrin, [that doesn't seem to be the case per Danny Parkins](http://twitter.com/#!/DannyParkins/status/27270837888): > _Per Pete Sala: 35,474 tickets sold at this moment for the Pitt game. > "Hoping for 40,000" is the word. Let me be clear, that's TERRIBLE_ > > _Normally I'd think SU is lowballing me so the figure is higher than > expectations, thus projecting a "success" but he gave me the exact #_ Harrumph. What's the deal, folks? Before OrangeChuck goes on a 3,000 word screed attacking your very sense of being in the comments below, let's try and get to the bottom of this. **Excuse No. 1 - "Eh, I Still Don't Believe The Hype"** Bro or Bro-ette, you gotta buy in eventually. If you don't jump on the bandwagon now you risk being completely left off from here on out. Obviously Syracuse fan all love one another, but we will be making mental notes of who isn't with us now and who decides to sneak on board later. You will not be one of us. You will be an outlander. [OUTLANDER](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fX5A2Yd90pg)! **Excuse No. 2 - "Even with all the deals, I still can't afford to bring my family."** Fair enough. Times are tough. But surely if you can't afford four tickets, you can still afford two. Better that you and your Little Orange in Training are there than none of you. **Excuse No. 3 - "I have a ridiculously-important exam on Monday, I can't afford to take time off from studying."** Listen, ten years from now, you will not remember that exam. You will not remember most anything from any of your classes. The only bits of knowledge from your Syracuse education that you will retain are a series of facts that will come in handy during dinner parties. _"Hey, did you know the difference between Doric and Ionic columns? Here, let me show you..."_ But you WILL remember every great moment at Syracuse basketball and football games. You will remember where you were when SU beat Pitt on a last-second touchdown, everyone stormed the field, you touched [Ryan Nassib](http://www.sbnation.com/ncaa-football/players/37776/ryan-nassib)'s arm as he ran past you and you woke up the next morning in the middle of the road on Comstock. Well, you won't remember what happened between the hours of 5pm and 5am the next morning...but you'll remember everything else. **Excuse No. 4 - "I don't like football."** Transfer to Siena. RIGHT NOW. We don't want you here. \---------- Look, the point is, if you were ever waiting for a good reason to go to a Syracuse football game, you will not find a better one. Not this season. There's no reason not to go to the game. The players have put their all into turning this team into something that Syracuse fans should want to cheer for inside the Dome...don't tell me they did it in vain. ## More From Troy Nunes Is An Absolute Magician * [Build your ultimate Syracuse men’s basketball lineup](https://www.nunesmagician.com/2020/4/6/21209106/build-your-ultimate-syracuse-orange-mbb-lineup-carmelo-pearl-mens-basketball) * [TNIAAM 2020 CNY Restaurant Bracket: The Field is Set!](https://www.nunesmagician.com/2020/4/6/21209225/tniaam-2020-cny-restaurant-bracket-the-field-is-set-syracuse-central-new-york-food) * [Where can you watch ‘classic’ Syracuse games? After waiting three years without a hearing, a petitioner has asked the
Superior Court of Guam to issue a writ of mandate to compel the Workers'
Compensation Commission to hear his case.

Victor Peter Zamora had filed a petition requesting a hearing regarding
workers' compensation benefits for an injury that allegedly occurred during
his employment in August 2015.

A proceeding was held Wednesday at Superior Court to discuss the petition.
During the proceedings, Zamora’s legal counsel, John Bell, told the court that
his client initially had filed a petition in October of this year.

According to documents filed in court, Zamora was employed as a reefer
assistant at Paul’s Roving Service in August 2015.

During his employment, Zamora developed an upper respiratory infection. He was
prescribed the drug levofloxacin under the brand name Levaquin, which resulted
in tendonitis, according to court documents. The petitioner filed a Form 201
on Aug. 26, 2015, providing notice of his work-related injury.

According to the petitioner, his workers' compensation claim was terminated in
bad faith by the commission, without any written findings or explanation.

The petitioner filed a formal request for a hearing on Nov. 16, 2015.
According to the petitioner, the commission failed to set a hearing for the
case.

Judge Elyze Iriarte ordered all parties to return to court on July 30, 2019.

# Real estate transactions: Oct. 7, 2016



### Friday

Oct 7, 2016 at 1:55 PM

  
  

These transactions, recorded the week of Sept. 26, are compiled from
information on file with the respective counties. They represent sales of
$78,000 or more.

PEORIA COUNTY

735 E. Gift Ave., Peoria, Robert J. and Mary L. Meis to Marcella West Lobdell,
$85,000.

#  'The river ripped him from me': A father, a son and a trip that turned
tragic in Interior Alaska

  * ![pencil](/pb/resources/assets/svg/icons/pencil-black.svg) Author: [Michelle Theriault Boots](/author/michelle-theriault-boots/)

  * ![clock](/pb/resources/assets/svg/icons/clock-black.svg) Updated: October 2, 2016 
  * ![calendar](/pb/resources/assets/svg/icons/calendar-black.svg) Published September 5, 2016 

![Gary Pitt, left, is pictured with his wife, De’ette Pitt, on the Goodpaster

When Gary Pitt and his son set off on one last trip up a river in Interior
Alaska last week, it was ostensibly to camp and hunt for moose.

But he was really looking for some closure — a way to say goodbye to the state
he had loved and explored for many years, and to his wife, who died in May.

Instead, the Goodpaster River snatched Gary Pitt in an instant when his boat
hit a logjam and sank Friday morning.

Troopers and volunteers have been searching the Tanana River tributary for
three days. They've found no sign of the 66-year-old miner and father of four.

His son thinks he drowned trying to save him.

"My guess is he tried to save me and fell in himself," said Gary Pitt II.

Gary Pitt had raised his family working as a miner in small towns all over the
West, from Elko, Nevada, to Lander, Wyoming.

Somewhere along the way, he'd fallen in love with Alaska. For the past decade
or so, he'd been working alongside one of his four sons at the Pogo Mine, an
underground gold mine northeast of Delta Junction, while living mostly in
Kenai.

Pitt and his wife were planning to retire on land they'd bought in a small
town in Texas, where they hoped to farm and ranch.

But before Pitt could permanently move down, his wife of nearly 45 years died
suddenly at the end of May.

"He was old-school when it came to his emotions. He always said he would show
us he loved us by what he did," said David Pitt, one of De'ette and Gary
Pitt's four sons.

But he was clearly devastated by his wife's death, David Pitt said.

Some of the family's happiest times had been far up the Goodpaster River,
known for its beauty, bounty and treacherous conditions.

A Fairbanks boat dealer even launched a ["Goodpaster
challenge,"](http://www.newsminer.com/the-goodpaster-challenge-fairbanks-
businessman-offers-to-anyone-who-
reaches/article_86861c40-fe52-5d20-aa9b-37c46883448e.html) in 2011, offering
$500 to anyone who could make it far enough up to take a photo with a sign
that said "If you can read this, you must be driving an SJX jetboat from
Compeau's."

For more than a dozen years, the Pitt family had taken boats up the river to
camp and hunt caribou and moose.

With all four Pitt brothers and their own kids, the group could total 15 or 20
people. The family would camp at a spot just above the Pogo Mine, at Mile 88
of the river. Only a few types of boats could make it up that far.

"It was kind of our bonding place," said David Pitt.

This summer, Gary Pitt wanted to see it one more time.

"He wanted to go one last time, because him and my mom — my mom loved going up
there," said Gary Pitt II, who lives in Kenai. "He just wanted some closure."

So last week, Gary Pitt and his eldest son bought their hunting permits,
loaded up their boat and drove north from Kenai. They put in their jet boat at
the Tanana River bridge toward the Pogo Mine. Part of the fun was always the
difficulty of getting to their spot.

"It's a very hard river to run," said Gary Pitt II. "It's twisty, braided."

But at about 10:30 a.m. Friday, they ran into trouble.

They'd just turned a corner at a spot about 3 miles south of the mine when
something got sucked up in one of the jet boat's engines, Pitt II said.

Before there was a chance to clear it out, the engine lost power and a
ferocious current forced the boat into a logjam. Within seconds, the boat
sank.

"It tea-cupped the boat, just filled it with water," Pitt II said.

Pitt II saw a flash of his father holding on to the logjam, he wrote in an
account he posted on Facebook. Then he was underwater himself for what he
thinks was close to a minute.

Suddenly, he felt like he was being grabbed by the top of both shoulders and
pulled up. Above the surface, he looked around. His father was about 5 feet
away, in the water but holding on to the logs.

He managed to pull himself up on the logs and crawled to his father.  He
grabbed him by the coat and yelled for him to hold on.

"I know he felt my grasp. I tried so hard, yelling and screaming for him to
hold on, to pull him up out of the water," Pitt II wrote. "I pulled and pulled
and could not bring him to me. I had no strength, nothing to bring even his
head up out of the water."

"He went so, so heavy," Pitt II wrote. "The river ripped him from me."  

**In shock**

Pitt II said he laid there on the logs, yelling for his father. No one
answered. Eventually, he was able to crawl off the logjam to the bank of the
river.

Someone he knew came down the river and saw him. They contacted troopers.

When medical help arrived, Pitt II had water in his lungs and was bordering on
hypothermia. He refused medical treatment. When he got back to his truck, he
drove all night. Back in Kenai, he went to church. People prayed over him.

The Alaska State Troopers, along with volunteers from the Pogo Mine, members
of the Fort Wainwright rescue and dive team and other river locals, have been
searching for Gary Pitt using aerial fly-overs in helicopters, plus river boat
patrols and underwater cameras.

Searchers have found no sign of Pitt. Troopers will continue to run periodic
aerial searches over the river, said spokesman Tim DeSpain.

Pitt II wrote out what happened in a Facebook post, thanking his father for
the life he gave his sons.

"He taught us boys with a firm hand and a loving heart and we love him for
that," he wrote.

Pitt II said he's been thinking about those fishing and hunting trips up the
river, and what they were really about.

"If there was one thing he wanted more than anything, it was a grizzly bear.
But for the most part, it wasn't about the hunt for him. It was about the time
being out there, together."
